page.title: 16BUNNY AND BRADMORE CHARITIES
page.content: The Bunny and Bradmore Charities were set up when Lady Anne Parkyns died in 1711. Her son Sir Thomas Parkyns built the Armshouses and the old Bunny school in 1700. The Charities provided money each year for the school and apprentices in Bunny, Bradmore and Costock. For a salary of Â£10 a year the headmaster taught the three "R's" and the Catechism. Before Christmas a Love_feast of cakes and ale was held. Children started school at 5 unless they could read. The schoolmaster lived on the first floor of the Arms- houses. The Armshouses included four rooms for four poor widows who got a new petticoat and gown every year at the love_feast. By 1908 the Charities gave Â£47 to apprentices living in Bunny, Bradmore and Costock. Today the Charities provide money for books and equipment for use in the school.
